instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2610: What is 820-2610? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Won't turn on
threads.message:
Guys,

I know this board is old, but i need to fix!
The costumer said, after start gets gray screen and another day the computer just don't turn on anymore.


I get:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (schematics is 6v but i get 8.2v)
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_CPU_IMVP_ISNS</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4v

I don't get:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>


I replaced <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> and works.

But the client bring back exactly the same problem.
So, i check <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> pin 1 and i get 0.34v. Something fuck up again this capacitor.

Do you guys can help me out?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Won't turn on
threads.message: Did you change it to a "normal" sized one?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Won't turn on
threads.message: i take for the same another board 2610 - the same model and size

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Won't turn on
threads.message: Yeah, bad idea. Change to normal sized 330uF. Got to run a bit of wire to hack it in.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Won't turn on
threads.message:
No Title

Duke, another one 330uF, but is more bigger then original one.
Take a look

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Won't turn on
threads.message: Yes, bodge it in there with a wire. I use the original GND pad and run a wire from the cap to the coil.
